Executive Summary 

The Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC Chicago facility is a chemical distribution plant located near Chicago, lllinios. The facility is part of Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC (Brenntag), headquartered in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin. Brenntag is an advanced distribution company serving customers worldwide with products, chemicals and advanced materials. The company ranks among the top chemical distribution firms in North America. 

It is the worldwide policy of Brenntag to design, blend and distribute its products, and to handle materials throughout their life cycle in a manner that protects the environment and safeguards employees, customers, and the public from unacceptable risk. This facility participates in the Responsible Distribution program of the Association of Chemical Distributors (ACD). The Community Outreach and Emergency Response Plan of Responsible Distribution brings chemical distribution plants and local communities together through communication and cooperative emergency planning. It is also company policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. 

The Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC Chicago facility is located at 4801 South Austin Ave. in an unincorporated area of Stickney Township, near Chicago, in Cook County, Illinois. Brenntag employs approximately 42 people at this location. The primary purpose of this facility is the distribution (including repackaging and storage) of industrial and fine chemicals. The regulated processes at this location include the storage and distribution of "factory-filled containers" of Cyclohexylamine and lsopropylamine, and the repackaging and storage of Aqua Ammonia. These chemicals are considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and are distributed to numerous customers who utilize these compounds for many 
applications ranging from water treatment, other chemical manufacturing, to pharmaceutical applications. The same properties that make these chemicals valuable, also makes

it necessary to observe certain safety precautions during handling and storage to reduce the threat to nearby members of our community, as well as to our employees. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State and local regulations. 
In accordance with the RMP Submit Users Manual 2004, the following elements and their descriptions have been included in this Executive Summary:

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Brenntag -is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as; design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the various processes at the facility. It is Brenntag's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, Brenntag has thoroughly coordinated response efforts with the Local Fire Dept., which provides highly trained emergency response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of a release.

2.	The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
The Brenntag facility's primary activities encompass distribution of chemical products. There are currently three (3) regulated substances present at the facility. These substances include Cyclohexylamine, lsopropylamine and Aqua Ammonia. The Cyclohexylamine and lsopropylamine are received prepackaged and are only handled for resell to customers and the containers are normally not opened on site. Aqua ammonia is repackaged from a DOT "in-transit" tanker truck to DOT totes.

3. 	Worst-Case Release Scenario
The EPA has defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint. Chapter 4 of the Risk Management Program Guidance for Chemical Distributors (40

CFR Part 68) 3/09 was used as a guideline for determining the worst-case release for each of the regulated substances.
The weight of the volume of liquid contained in the largest container of each regulated substance was used to determine the release rate. LFA, LFB and DF values were taken from Exhibit 4-5a tables. A temperature correction factor (Exhibit 4-6) was chosen for a temperature of 101 deg F, which is the highest daily maximum temperature for the local vicinity over the past five years. A non­diked pool was calculated to be 224 square feet assuming the spilled liquid forms a 1 cm deep pool. This information was used, along with Exhibits provided in the guidance manual, in order to determine the distance to the endpoint. Based on site topography and satellite photos of the surrounding area, an urban topography was chosen for this facility. 
The worst-case release calculations for isopropylamine indicate that there are no public receptors within the distance to the endpoint. This, in addition to no accidents with specific offsite consequences within the last five years, classifies this process as a Program Level 1 regulated substances. As such, an alternative release scenario (ARS) is not required. 

The worst-case release calculations for cyclohexylamine and aqua ammonia indicate that there are potential public (industrial) receptors within the distance to the toxic endpoint. This, in addition to no accidents with specific offsite consequences within the last five years, classifies both of these processes as a Program Level 2 regulated substances. Alternative release scenarios (ARS)'s were calculated for each chemical and resulted in less of the distance to the toxic endpoints than the worst-case scenarios. 

4. 	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps The Brenntag facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68 of th

e EPA.
The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is currently in place at the stationary source. 

Process Safety Information - Quality Assurance & Regulatory Manager 
Brenntag maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. 
Process Hazard Analysisv- Quality Assurance & Regulatory Manager (Chairman of the Hazard Process Review Team 

Brenntag conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the distribution processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is "WHAT IF" The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of three years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. 

Operating Procedures-Warehouse Manager\Foreman 
Brenntag maintains written operating procedures for the purposes of safely conducting activities associated with the distribution processes. These procedures address various modes of operation such as used in normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes. 

Training - Manager of Health, Safety and Quality 
Brenntag has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years, and more frequently, as needed. 

Mechanical Integrity - Warehouse Manager\Fo

reman 
Brenntag carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions. Maintenance checks are performed on process equipment also includes lift trucks and tractor/trailer trucks. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training, as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. Outside contractors also participate in the maintenance process. 

Management of Change - Regional Manager of Quality, Safety, health and Environmental
Written procedures are in place at Brenntag to manage changes in chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions, are promptly made aware of the modification and offered appropriate training. 

Pre-startup Reviews - Regional Manager of Quality, Safety, health and Environmental
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of established processes, are conducted as a regular practice at Brenntag. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. 

Compliance Audits - Regional Manager of Quality, Safety, health and Environmental
Brenntag conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set forth under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions resulting from the audits are undertaken in a safe and timely manner. 

Incident Investigation - Regional Manager of Quality, Safety, health and Environmental 
Brenntag promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated subs

tance. These investigations are conducted to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as to determine corrective actions that will prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. 

Employee Participation-Operations Manager 
Brenntag truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, employees have access to all information developed for the RMP rule along with information resulting from process hazard analyses. 

Contractors- Warehouse Manager\Foreman 
On occasion, Brenntag hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is conducted. Brenntag has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event that a regulated substance is accidentally released.

5.	Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of Cyclohexylamine, lsopropylamine or Aqua Ammonia in the past five (5) years. No one on or off-site has ever been injured and no evacuation measures have ever been taken.

6.	Emergency Response Plan
Brenntag has a written emergency response plan in place to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes that take place

within the processes that would require a modified emergency response. 
The Emergency Response Plan has been reviewed, coordinated and verified with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). 

7. 	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Brenntag's safety program is designed to prevent fires, explosions, and accidental chemical releases. The program requires safety audits, inspection, maintenance programs, and safety training for employees and contract workers. Facility personnel are always encouraged to listen to the concerns of the community and to consider these concerns when designing and implementing process safety systems.

Brenntag continues to improve its safety record by conducting incident investigations and safety compliance audits. Brenntag also utilizes continuous training on emergency procedures, and participating in outreach activities, which include: educating and training customers, fire departments, and emergency response teams. Brenntag practices continuous training of emergency procedures through regular safety meetings, and all incidents and near misses are thoroughly investigated and reviewed by the Health and Safety personnel and the Safety Committee at each facility. 

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the Brenntag accidental release prevention program. Brenntag constantly strives to improve the safety of the processes at the facility through both the incident investigation program, and the safety committee. Brenntag will continue to train employees in the operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed. 

END
